choices.text: Exploration of the kidney to be done in all cases
Lumbar approach to kidney is preferred

questions.text: Which of the following is true about renal trauma? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is correct as if a patient suffers from a renal trauma we need to know the functionality of the kidney before we operate and take definitive steps towards the treatment so we have to order an IVP in order to know the functioning status of the kidney. Option B is wrong as most of the patients of renal trauma are tried to be managed conservatively and exploration is indicated in very few patients who are hemodynamically unstable. Option C is false as we do not go for a lumbar approach while operating a patient with renal trauma as in these patients there is a high likelihood that patient has some accompanying other intra abdominal injury and if we go via a midline approach we can manage the condition in a better way. Option D is wrong as renal artery aneurysm is uncommon after a renal trauma.

questions.text: Which does not happen in unilateral renal trauma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) as far as one of the kidneys of the patient is functioning properly he will not have uraemia as the normally functioning kidney will take care of the patient’s blood urea. Option A is hypertension and even if one kidney of the patient is damaged, patient can suffer from hypertension due to excessive renin secreted by the normally functioning kidney. Option C is clot formation and that can definitely occur in a unilateral renal trauma. Option D is perinephric hematoma and this can also occur depending on the amount of damage to the kidney.

choices.text: Exploration is indicated in 90% of cases

questions.text: In renal trauma, which statement is not correct? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer as in most of the cases while managing the patient of renal trauma unless the patient is hemodynamically unstable we go for conservative management of the patient. Option B is correct as hematuria is a cardinal sign of renal trauma in most of the cases. Option C is correct as while operating a patient of renal trauma we prefer transperitoneal approach as we can assess injury to other intra abdominal organs during the operation and take necessary measures if needed. Options D is correct as in patients of renal trauma we need to assess the functionality of contralateral kidney and functionality of the injured kidney so we perform an IVP to assess this.

questions.text: Absolute indication for surgical exploration after renal trauma? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The absolute indication of exploration In case of renal trauma is pulsatile hematoma . Hematuria and cortical renal contusion are not the absolute indications for surgical exploration.

choices.text: Contrast enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of abdomen

questions.text: A 25 years old male presents to emergency with history of road traffic accident two hours ago. The patient is hemodynamically stable. Abdomen is soft. On catheterization of the bladder, hematuria is noticed. The next step in the management should be: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) This case scenario talks about a patient who is hemodynamically stable after road traffic accident and has renal injury which is indicated by the passing of blood on catheterization of bladder. This indicates a renal injury and to know the grade of renal injury we need to go forward and do a CECT as the patient is hemodynamically stable. Option A that is immediate laparotomy would have been the answer is patient would have been hemodynamically unstable. Option B that is retrograde cystourethrogram would have been the answer if patient would have had blood at the meatus, this would have been done to rule out urethral injury. Option C is done only when a patient of blunt abdominal trauma is hemodynamically unstable and FAST is equivocal and we need to decide whether the patient needs an operation.

questions.text: Which one of the following veins should be avoided for intravenous infusion in the management of abdominal trauma? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) we always prefer upper extremity vein as compared to lower extremity veins. Lower extremity veins is avoided because: • To prevent DVT • To preserve the long saphenous vein, as it is used for arterial grafting in case of vascular injury

choices.text: Inform police before starting the treatment

questions.text: A female with suspected child abuse was brought to the casualty with severe bleeding from perineum. What should be the first line of management? (AIIMS Nov. 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Primary survey of ATLS consists of ABCDE as A is the first component ,the first step in trauma management is maintenance of airway. A: Airway and cervical spine position B: Breathing C: Circulation with hemorrhage control D: Disability E: Exposure

questions.text: Most common organ involved in blunt injury to the abdomen: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common organ injured in blunt trauma of abdomen is spleen Most common organ injured in penetrating trauma of abdomen is liver If question specifically asks most common organ injured in gun shot injury of abdomen the answer is small intestine

questions.text: Investigation of choice for blunt trauma abdomen in unstable patient: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Whenever you encounter a patient of blunt abdominal trauma first thing you need to assess is the hemodynamic stability of the patient. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable you take the patient for FAST (Focused assessment sonogram for trauma). FAST is nothing but a USG examination done in the casualty to look for intraperitoneal fluid accumulation. And based on the results of FAST further management is determined so USG is the investigation of choice for blunt abdominal trauma in an unstable patient. Xray can be done to look for gas under diaphragm and rule out visceral perforation but it is not the investigation of choice Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is reserved for the group of patients who are hemodynamically unstable and in whom FAST is inconclusive MRI has no role in acute case of blunt abdominal trauma CT scan is investigation of choice for a patient of blunt abdominal trauma who is hemodynamically stable

questions.text: Investigation of choice for diagnosing intra abdominal bleeding in a stable patient: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Whenever you encounter a patient of blunt abdominal trauma first thing you need to assess is the hemodynamic stability of the patient. CECT is IOC in stable patients; FAST is IOC for unstable blunt trauma.FAST is nothing but a USG examination done in the casualty to look for intraperitoneal fluid accumulation. And based on the results of FAST further management is determined so USG is the initial investigation to be done for blunt abdominal trauma in a stable patient. But the investigation of choice for a patient of blunt abdominal trauma who is hemodynamically stable is CECT Xray can be done to look for gas under diaphragm and rule out visceral perforation but it is not the investigation of choice Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is reserved for the group of patients who are hemodynamically unstable and in whom FAST is inconclusive MRI has no role in acute case of blunt abdominal trauma CT scan is investigation of choice for a patient of blunt abdominal trauma who is hemodynamically stable IOC for blunt abdominal trauma in hemodynamically unstable patient : FAST Initial investigation for blunt abdominal trauma in hemodynamically unstable patient : FAST IOC for blunt abdominal trauma in hemodynamically stable patient : CECT Initial investigation for blunt abdominal trauma in hemodynamically stable patient : FAST

questions.text: A driver wearing seat belt applied brake suddenly to avoid accident. Most common organ injured in seat belt injury: (AllMS May 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) First understand the mechanism behind seat belt injury. In seat belt injury the driver is wearing a seat belt and he suddenly comes to a stop because of collision. Because of the inertia the body along with the mobile intra abdominal organs tend to move forward. As the driver is wearing the seat belt he is restained from moving forward. So a distraction force develops at the junction of mobile intra abdominal organs and the retroperitoneal fixed structures. MAIN INJURIES TO OCCUR IN SEAT BELT INJURY ARE AT THE JUNCTION OF MOBILE AND NON MOBILE INTRA ABDOMINAL ORGANS.As one part of the mesentery is attached to retroperitoneum and other end is attached to mobile intra abdominal organ mesentry injury is very common in seat belt injury. Duodenal jejunal flexure is another such part which is injured in seat belt injury. Option A, B and D are wrong as seat belt injury does not cause injury at these organs.

questions.text: Preferred incision for abdominal exploration in blunt injury abdomen is (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Whenever you operate in a patient of blunt abdominal injury the operation is known as exploratory laparotomy, and in this we put a straight vertical incision extending from xiphi sternum till pubic symphysis. We need this vertical midline incision to gain access and adequate exposure to all the organs in the abdominal cavity. Option B is wrong as we can never know all the organs injured and the degree of their injury when we operate on a patient with blunt abdominal injury. Option C and D are wrong as these incisions do not provide adequate exposure for exploratory laparotomy.

questions.text: Best diagnostic test in stable patient with blunt trauma abdomen is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CECT is the investigation of choice for a patient of blunt abdominal trauma who is hemodynamically stable FAST is the investigation of choice for a patient of blunt abdominal trauma who is hemodynamically unstable DPL is reserved for those patients of blunt abdominal trauma who are hemodynamically unstable but FAST is inconclusive MRI has no role in the setting of acute management in blunt abdominal trauma patients

choices.text: Insertion of abdominal drain followed by laparotomy

questions.text: A patient with abdominal injury presents to the emergency department with signs of signs of peritonitis and shock. Airway and breathing were secured and IV fluids were started with 2 large bore cannulas. The next line of management should be: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This case scenario describes a patient who has developed peritonitis after a blunt abdominal trauma and the only reason for this has to be breach in the bowel integrity due to trauma and spillage of the intra bowel contents into peritoneal cavity leading to peritonitis. If this is a presentation you don’t need to any test in this patient, just take the patient straight away for an exploratory laparotomy. Option A is false as even if you do FAST in this patient your management is not going to change, you will just end up delaying the management of the patient. Option C is false as this might deteriorate the patient even futher as we are not addressing the actual cause of peritonitis Option D is false as laparoscopy has no role in management of a patient with acute abdominal trauma.

questions.text: True about abdominal compartment syndrome:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, D) Physiologic Consequences of Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure Decreased:- • Cardiac output • Central venous return • Visceral blood flow • Renal blood flow • Glomerular filtration Increased: • Cardiac rate • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure • Peak inspiratory pressure • Central venous pressure • Intrapleural pressure • Systemic vascular resistance

choices.text: Hypoxia due to increased peak inspiratory pressure
Hypotension due to decrease in venous return

questions.text: Abdominal compartment syndrome is characterized by the following except (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) oliguria occurs due to decreased renal blood flow and does not occur due to ureteric obstruction. Option A is correct as hypercarbia and respiratory acidosis is a feature of abdominal compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Organ most commonly damaged in penetrating injury of abdomen is: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common organ injured in penetrating abdominal injury is liver. Most common organ injured in blunt abdominal injury is spleen Most common organ injured in gunshot injury is small intestine. Duodenum is retroperitoneal structure and is injured rarely and most of the times the injury is because of penetrating injury rather than blunt abdominal trauma.

questions.text: A child presents in causality in stable condition after a blunt abdominal trauma associated with splenic trauma. Treatment of choice is: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In this case scenario as patient is hemodynamically stable so we can put the patient on conservative management and observation. Conservative management means we need to put the patient on serial abdominal examinations, monitor abdominal girth, record BP and pulse at serial intervals and repeat CT Abdomen and pelvis every 24 hours if needed. if anytime during the conservative management if patient becomes hemodynamically unstable then operative managent is preferred. Arterial embolization, splenorrhaphy and splenectomy are undertaken if the patient is hemodynamically unstable. Arterial embolization is specifically helpful if CT scan shows an arterial blush on angiography which can be treated with embolization.

choices.text: Spleen is most common organ to be involved
For grade V injury treatment is conservative

questions.text: True about blunt abdominal trauma with splenic rupture: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) spleen is the most common organ injured in blunt abdominal trauma Liver is the most common organ injured in penetrating abdominal trauma. Kehr’s sign is seen in splenic rupture with sub diaphragmatic blood collection. The blood collected in sub diaphragmatic space irritates the diaphragm and causes a referred pain to the left shoulder. Conservative management is the treatment of choice for splenic trauma. Splenectomy is a last resort for the treatment of splenic injury. Cullen’s sign is seen in acute pancreatitis and denotes periumbilical discoulouration.

choices.text: Treatment is simple debridement and suturing
Blood in stomach is always related to gastric injury

questions.text: Which of the following statements related to gastric injury is not true? (AllMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) blood in stomach does not always represent a gastric injury, most of the times it is because of bleeding from some above source in esophagus or oropharynx and has trickled down into the stomach. Sometimes is is caused by stress ulcer in the stomach. So blood in stomach does not necessarily tells that there is a gastric injury . Option A is correct as most of the gastric injuries are caused by a penetrating trauma rather than blunt abdominal trauma. If there is breach in the wall of the stomach, its treatment is simple debridment and suturing which heals well and fast as stomach has a rich blood supply which facilitates early healing of the stomach.

choices.text: Head injury due to wind screen

questions.text: Seat belt causes injury to: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) First understand the mechanism behind seat belt injury. In seat belt injury the driver is wearing a seat belt and he suddenly comes to a stop because of collision. Because of the inertia the body along with the mobile intra abdominal organs tend to move forward. As the driver is wearing the seat belt he is restrained from moving forward. So a distraction force develops at the junction of mobile intra abdominal organs and the retroperitoneal fixed structures. MAIN INJURIES TO OCCUR IN SEAT BELT INJURY ARE AT THE JUNCTION OF MOBILE AND NON MOBILE INTRA ABDOMINAL ORGANS. So as duodenal jejunal flexure is one such part,seat belt injury causes injury at this part of intestine. Option B and C are wrong as seat belt injury does not cause injury at these organs.

questions.text: When bullet is shot above pubic symphysis in midline directed backwards, first organ to get injuries is? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) When bullet is shot above pubic symphysis in midline directed backwards, first organ to get injuries is abdominal aorta Option C and D can not be the answer in this case as these structures are not in the midline. Option A that is bladder lies in the pelvis and is protected by bony pelvis it becomes an abdominal organ only in the distended state. So the answer to this question is B .

questions.text: Which manure has been shown in the figure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mattox Maneuver, also known as a left medial visceral rotation, is a surgical step to explore and handle Zone 1 and 2 retroperitoneal injuries (aorta, left iliac and pelvic vessels). It starts with incising the parietal peritoneum at the white line of Toldt from the sigmoid colon to the splenic flexure. The spleen, tail of the pancreas, left kidney, and stomach are mobilized and reflected medially during this maneuver to explore the deeper structures. Option B. The Cattell–Braasch manoeuvre begins at the common bile duct and ends at the ligament of Treitz. It allows you to mobilise the whole duodenum, pancreas head, small bowel and the right colon and bring the two last structures outside the abdomen. Thanks to anatomical knowledge of the avascular planes – the Cattell–Braasch manoeuvre is the one of the quickest mobilisation surgical techniques with minimal blood loss. Extended Kocher’s manoeuvre is a part of Cattell–Braasch manoeuvre and generally consists of full exposition of the inferior vena cava (IVC), renal veins, abdominal aorta, and superior mesenteric artery (SMA).

questions.text: If bleeding continues to come even after performing the following maneuver what is the source of the bleed ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The Pringle maneuver is a surgical maneuver used in some abdominal operations. A large atraumatic hemostat is used to clamp the hepatoduodenal ligament (free border of the lesser omentum) interrupting the flow of blood through the hepatic artery and the portal vein and thus helping to control bleeding from the liver. More commonly, in the absence of soft clamp, manual compression of the hepatoduodenal ligament is performed. Should bleeding continue, it is likely that the inferior vena cava or the hepatic vein were also traumatised. If bleeding continues, a variation in arterial blood flow may be present.

questions.text: What is the most common complication following open splenectomy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Complications following splenectomy can be divided into pulmonary, haemorrhagic, infectious, pancreatic, and thromboembolic. Pulmonary complications include left lower lobe atelectasis, pleural effusion, and pneumonia left lower lobe atelectasis being the most common complication overall.

choices.text: Penetrating trauma in pelvic region should be explored always
All zone 1 vascular injuries should be managed with embolization
Zone 2 penetrating injuries with expanding haematoma should be explored surgically
Mattox manoeuvre is when the ascending colon is mobilized to right to expose the aorta

questions.text: In retroperitoneal haematomas . which one of the following statements is true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Zone 1= from aortic hiatus to sacral promontory. Zone 2= from renal hilum upto lateral wall. Zone 3= Iliac vessel zone. Treatment is based on mechanism of injury:- 1. Penetrating→ Surgery in all. 2. Blunt injury→Surgery in Zone 1 except retrohepatic IVC hematoma which can be treated conservatively, Zone 2 & 3 → non-operative management In Zone 2 → surgery → if expanding hematoma In Zone 3 → if active bleed →Angioembolization. Mattox maneuver is when descending colon is mobilized. Cattel Brasch Maneuver is when ascending colon is mobilized to right to expose the aorta.

choices.text: Subdural and dural trauma can be identified

questions.text: What is additional benefit of e-FAST over conventional FAST?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Pelvic trauma can be identified on normal FAST scan also. Option B-Chest Trauma can be identified by eFAST as An 'extended FAST or eFAST ' scan may be performed using left & right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax & hemothorax. Option C,D-Subdural and dural trauma and Retroperitoneal trauma cannot be evaluated on FAST or eFAST.

questions.text: Patient of RTA With grade-3 splenic trauma, on non-operative management in ward. What would be the reason for Laparotomy on second day of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Fall in Hb more than 3gm would need laparotomy. Option B-Presence of Pneumoperitoneum would need laparotomy as there maybe perforation of hollow viscera. Option C-Extraperitoneum rupture of bladder is managed by putting Foley's catheter. Option D-Distended GB is not an indication for laparotomy.

questions.text: Which vaccine is not given after splenectomy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Typhoid vaccine is not given after splenectomy. Option B,C,D-Post splenectomy,there is increased risk of encapsulated bacterial infections,hence,patient should be given vaccine against encapsulated organisms such as Pneumococcal,Meningococcal and H influenzae vaccine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency room after a gunshot wound to the abdomen. On arrival, he is hypotensive (BP 60/30 mmHg), tachycardic (HR 140 bpm), and hypothermic (34°C). Which of the following findings during laparotomy would indicate the need for damage control surgery rather than definitive surgical repair?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Persistent coagulopathy during surgery Indicators for switching to DCS include the lethal triad of hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy. Persistent coagulopathy suggests the patient cannot tolerate a prolonged operation, and DCS should be performed to stabilize the patient before definitive repair

choices.text: Mobilizing the hepatic flexure and duodenum

questions.text: A patient with blunt abdominal trauma is undergoing surgery. To expose the entire retroperitoneum and major vessels on the right side, the surgeon performs the Cattell-Braasch maneuver. What is the key step in this procedure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mobilizing the hepatic flexure and duodenum The Cattell-Braasch maneuver is performed to expose the right retroperitoneum, including the right kidney, inferior vena cava (IVC), and aorta. It involves mobilization of the right colon and duodenum by incising their peritoneal attachments. This maneuver is often used to expose major vascular injuries on the right side of the abdomen.
